topics.title: Using Zener Diodes for Regulating Voltage
topics.description: How Zener diodes can be used to regulate voltage and protect circuits from overvoltage.
topics.coverage_text:
There is a line in the cathode side of real diodes to specify a negative or cathode side. Look here,
this silver line here and this one.
This diode specifies the cathode side by a black line.
If you change this line to a shape like S, first letter of Schottky, it becomes a Schottky diode
schematic symbol like this. And if you replace this line with a shape like Z, first letter of Zener,
it becomes a Zener diode schematic symbol. And if you surround the diode symbol with a circle,
it becomes an LED symbol. This component will allow current to flow in this direction from its
anode to its cathode and it will block current in opposite direction. If you put voltage to diode in
right order, I mean positive voltage to anode pin and negative voltage to cathode pin, then your diode

topics.description: A simple example of using a Zener diode to protect circuits from overvoltage.

topics.title: Using LEDs for Remote Communication
topics.description: How LEDs can be used for remote communication and controlling devices.
topics.coverage_text:
It seems easy, but you have to be careful in selecting proper diode. These are three important
parameters to consider in selecting diode. All of these parameters are available in data sheet.
In data sheet of every diode, it is available to check how much voltage the diode will tolerant in reverse
by a setup. For example, if you are going to rectify AC power in United States by a half wave rectifier,
you can use these, but you can't use these because of shortage of reverse blocking voltage.
Contrary to what most newbies think, application of diodes is not limited to rectification.
Second application of diodes is my favorite. Application number two.
Using diode for reverse polarity protection to protect or product from inverted polarity.
Think about your product. The result of all those efforts can be lost with just a small mistake.
If the user connects power supply in wrong polarity, main parts of your circuit will blow up.
